title: Business News:  ESPN Sells Stake in X Games  ----  By Joseph De Avila
text:
ESPN has sold its controlling interest in the X Games, the extreme-sports competition franchise, to private-equity firm MSP Sports Capital.

MSP Sports will hold a majority stake in the X Games and handle day-to-day operations of the competition, the companies said. ESPN will retain a minority stake and continue to broadcast the X Games under a multiyear agreement. Walt Disney Co. owns ESPN.

Terms of the sale weren't disclosed.

Founded in the 1990s, the X Games introduced extreme sports to mainstream audiences, with events including competitive skateboarding, snowboarding and freestyle BMX.

"We're proud of what we've created with our employees and the athletes over nearly 30 years of world-class X Games events and content," Jimmy Pitaro, chairman of ESPN and sports content, said in a statement.

MSP has previously made investments in four European soccer teams as well as McLaren Racing Ltd., the British motor-racing team.

Jahm Najafi, chairman of MSP, said the firm will use its sports expertise to bring new energy to the X Games brand.

The acquisition highlights the growing trend of investment firms seeking to capitalize on sports. Several firms have formed in recent years specializing in sports-related deals.

MSP also said it named Steven Flisler as chief executive of the X Games. Mr. Flisler recently served as vice president of original content at Twitch, the streaming platform owned by Amazon.com Inc.

Skateboarding legend Tony Hawk, who has 10 gold medals from the X Games, was named a brand steward for the competition. Mr. Hawk made history at the 1999 X Games when he executed a 900-degree, 2 1/2-turn twist, after attempting it for 12 years.

"Being part of the advisory board for X Games is an extension of my decades of competing and much more forgiving to the body," Mr. Hawk said.

The next X Games will take place in Aspen, Colo., in January.
